properties.description: Up to 90% of people living with dementia will experience distressed behaviour as a result of unmet needs, but the majority of it is preventable. We’ve built the first AI tool that predicts distressed behaviour in dementia care, before it happens, giving carers real-time & evidence-based support to prevent distress, prevent crises, reduce medication, and meet people's needs effectively.
properties.how_does_your_company_use_innovation__th:
We’re combining behavioural science with machine learning to do something that hasn’t been done before in dementia care: predict distressed behaviour before it happens.

Instead of waiting for things to go wrong and reacting in crisis, Less Distress is an app that uses real-world care data to spot early warning signs and guide carers in real time. It’s personalised, preventative, and based on the science of why behaviour happens in the first place, something most systems completely ignore.

Our innovation isn’t just in the tech, it’s in the model. We’re giving frontline carers access to the kind of behavioural insight that’s usually locked away in specialist services, and doing it in a way that’s fast, affordable, easy to use on the job, and a globally scalable solution.
properties.how_does_your_product_contribute_to_a_he:
Less Distress is about making things better for everyone involved in dementia care: The person, the carer, and the family.

All behaviour happens for a reason. In dementia, that reason is often an unmet need, but it’s very hard for carers to understand what the need is without proper training (which they very rarely receive). We help carers see what the behaviour is trying to say, so they can respond in a way that meets the need, not just manages the reaction.

When carers can predict distress before it happens, they can step in early and calmly, rather than reacting in crisis. Right now, when distressed behaviour is difficult for carers to support with, people are given unlicensed antipsychotics just to keep them sedated even though the side effects can be devastating: sedation, stroke, and death. It’s not person-centred care, it’s damage control.

Less Distress helps change that. We give carers real tools, grounded in behavioural science, so they can reduce medication, prevent placement breakdowns, and support the person effectively. That means more dignity, more calm, and more moments where people feel understood, not lost.

When it feels like no one cares...emwillcare
properties.name: emwillcare
properties.please_expand:
I’m not just looking for money, I’m looking for real partnership that brings not just funding, but support, mentorship, and guidance from people who’ve done this before and can help me take what I’ve started and turn it into something huge.

The AI company we’re working with built our prototype for free, and they’re still developing with us at no cost, because they believe in what we’re doing. It's the same with our marketing support. People are giving their time and skills because they’ve seen the impact that I have as a behaviour analyst, and they believe in me to make it happen.

In July, I’ll be pitching to investors for the first time at an Alzheimer’s Society event. I know my field, I’m one of only 80 behavioural analysts in the world who specialise in dementia. What I need now is someone who can help me build this into a service that’s available to everyone who needs it at a devastating time in their life.

I’m here to deliver and I’m the right person for this job. I’ll be the best entrepreneur you’ve ever worked with. I care for the people I help and want to make their lives better on a wider scale than I can do in-person. I make change happen, I’ve done it all my life (I started my other business 4 years ago, the first behavioural consultancy business in the UK for dementia care). And now I’m ready to do it on a much bigger scale to help millions of people.
properties.what_best_describes_your_stage_of_busine: I have a business that I want to scale
properties.what_is_your_usp__what_makes_you_differe:
There are currently no competitors in the field. I’m one of only 80 behaviour analysts in the whole world specialising in dementia care, and I’ve spent years working directly with carers, trying to stop distress before it spirals into crisis. However, there is only so many people I can help in-person.

'Less Distress', by emwillcare takes my knowledge and expertise and is the first tool that actually predicts distressed behaviour using behavioural science and AI, not just tracking what’s already gone wrong, but helping carers know what to do next, in real time. This isn’t just innovation, it’s a lifeline for caregivers.

We are supported by the Alzheimer's Society Launchpad programme, and Business Wales Accelerator Growth Programme.
properties.where_is_your_business_based_: UK but wanting to scale to US

structured_data.executive_summary: Revolutionising dementia care with behavioural science and AI, the company aims to predict distress, prevent crisis, and support carers, making distress the exception rather than the expectation.
structured_data.problem_statement: Dementia care faces increased health and social care costs, high staff churn rates (30% average), inappropriate use of unlicensed antipsychotic drugs with nasty side effects, inability to support behaviours resulting from dementia, and high onboarding costs for new care staff (£3642 each). Dementia care costs the UK £34.7 billion/year, expected to hit £94.1 billion by 2040.
structured_data.solution: An AI-powered behavioural support platform for dementia carers that automates the assessment and prevention of distressed behaviours in people with dementia. The platform uses evidence-based scientific principles and AI-driven behavioural science to identify triggers and patterns, providing personalised, actionable strategies.
structured_data.product_service_description: A digital healthcare platform where caregivers log distressed behaviours. The AI-driven system analyses the data to identify triggers and patterns, and provides a recommendation engine with personalised, actionable strategies to reduce distress, improve care, and prevent unnecessary medication.
structured_data.market_size_opportunity: Dementia care costs the UK £34.7 billion/year, expected to reach £94.1 billion by 2040, indicating a large and growing market opportunity.
structured_data.team: Dr Emma Williams is the founder. The pitch also references 'Jess', the dog who inspired the solution.
structured_data.traction_milestones: Advance assurance in place for SEIS & EIS. MVP digital platform built. Pilot run in care homes using real-world data. Positioning for larger NHS and care provider contracts. AI model refinement underway.
structured_data.go_to_market_strategy: Run pilot in care homes, refine AI model using real-world data, and position for larger NHS and care provider contracts.

founder_profiles.name: Emma Williams
founder_profiles.role_in_company: Corporate Vice President of Modern Work Transformation, M365
founder_profiles.background_summary: Emma Williams is a seasoned technology executive with over 18 years at Microsoft. She currently serves as Corporate Vice President of Modern Work Transformation, responsible for planning and building Office 365 solutions built on Microsoft Teams for industry verticals such as Healthcare, Financial Services, Government, Retail, and Manufacturing. She also leads the Microsoft Viva Insights product. Throughout her career at Microsoft, she has demonstrated a strong focus on user experience design, ethical AI principles, and embedding empathy into product development. She is particularly passionate about serving underrepresented users and frontline workers.

previous_companies.description: Led redesign of consumer-grade experiences for broader market relevance and younger consumer appeal to grow market share. Drove company UX effort for ethical AI design, promoting balance of EQ and IQ in product development to amplify human ingenuity.
Led the focus for broadening appeal for Xbox to be 'more than just games', expanding the platform's reach beyond traditional gaming audiences.
Led BMC Software's flagship enterprise management product, Patrol Enterprise Manager, in Silicon Valley.

public_speaking_or_content.title: How modern collaboration tools enhance patient outcomes across healthcare
Microsoft Cloud for Healthcare helps empower care teams with better experiences, better insights, and better care
Empowering care teams with new tools in Microsoft 365
CNBC Squawk Box Asia appearance discussing workplace transformations
Bloomberg Live: Work Shifting 2.0: Redefining Normal

investment_criteria_assessment.assessment_summary: Inferred from web search as research_prospect_tool failed. Emma Williams has strong focus industry fit (technology, specifically Microsoft's Modern Work division). Her work shows mission alignment through focus on employee wellbeing and empowering frontline workers. She has impressive experience at Microsoft (18+ years) in strategic roles and demonstrates exceptional strategic thinking through her leadership in ethical AI design and user experience. No evidence found of founding previous companies.

company_profile.description: emwillcare is a healthtech company focused on transforming dementia care by providing evidence-based, innovative solutions that empower caregivers and improve the quality of life for individuals living with dementia. Their approach combines behavioural science and smart technology to reduce distress, minimize medication use, and lower care costs.
company_profile.sub_industry: Dementia Care, Digital Health, Behavioural Science
key_products_services: Less Distress (digital tool for predicting and preventing distressed behaviours in dementia care)
Behavioural science-based consultancy and training for care providers
company_profile.business_model: B2B SaaS and consultancy: emwillcare provides digital tools and evidence-based training to care homes, health and social care providers, and commissioners, typically on a subscription or service contract basis.
company_profile.target_customer: Care home owners, commissioners, clinical teams, and caregivers seeking cost-effective, evidence-based solutions to improve dementia care and reduce distress.
company_profile.mission_statement: To transform dementia care by ensuring individuals living with dementia receive the best possible support, while empowering their caregivers with effective, evidence-based strategies. emwillcare is committed to reducing placement breakdowns, minimizing the use of unlicensed antipsychotic drugs, and lowering health and social care costs—all while improving the quality of life for those affected by dementia.

market_analysis.industry_overview: Health technology (health-tech) encompasses the application of organized knowledge and skills in the form of devices, medicines, vaccines, procedures, and systems developed to solve health problems and improve quality of life. The industry includes pharmaceuticals, medical devices, digital health solutions (such as telemedicine, electronic health records, wearable devices, and health apps), and organizational systems used in healthcare. Health-tech aims to enhance the delivery of health services, improve patient outcomes, and increase efficiency in healthcare systems.
market_analysis.target_market_segment: Key segments include healthcare providers (hospitals, clinics), payers (insurance companies), patients/consumers (via telehealth, wearables, and health apps), pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies, and government/public health agencies. There is a growing focus on chronic disease management, preventive care, remote patient monitoring, and personalized medicine.
market_analysis.market_size_tam: $908.5B (2023), projected to reach $3,140.9B by 2033 (Allied Market Research, HealthTech Market). Other estimates for digital health alone range from $288.55B (2024, Grand View Research) to $362.36B (2024, Precedence Research).
market_analysis.market_growth_rate_cagr: 13.1% (2024-2033, Allied Market Research); other sources cite 11.68% (2025-2034, Precedence Research) and up to 18.7% (2024-2028, EIN Presswire) depending on subsegment.
key_market_trends: Accelerated digital transformation and adoption of telemedicine and remote patient monitoring.
Integration of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning for diagnostics, personalized medicine, and operational efficiency.
Expansion of wearable health devices and mobile health (mHealth) applications.
Growth in cloud-based healthcare IT solutions and interoperability initiatives.
Increased focus on preventive care, chronic disease management, and aging populations.
Rising investment in digital health startups and M&A activity.
Consumerization of healthcare: patients seeking more control and access to health data and services.
Regulatory evolution to address data privacy, cybersecurity, and digital therapeutics.
market_analysis.competitor_landscape_summary: The global health-tech market is highly fragmented, with both established multinational corporations and rapidly growing startups. Major players span medical devices, digital health platforms, telemedicine, and AI-driven solutions. The market is characterized by significant investment, frequent M&A, and a race to develop interoperable, scalable, and regulatory-compliant solutions. Market share is distributed among a mix of technology giants, specialized health-tech firms, and traditional healthcare companies expanding into digital health.

competitors.name: Siemens Healthineers AG
strengths: Global presence in medical imaging, diagnostics, and digital health solutions
Strong R&D and innovation pipeline
Established relationships with healthcare providers

competitors.name: Medtronic
strengths: Leading medical device manufacturer with digital health integration
Strong brand and distribution network
Diverse product portfolio

competitors.name: EPIC Systems Corporation
strengths: Dominant player in electronic health records (EHR)
Large installed base and high switching costs (vendor lock-in)
Comprehensive healthcare IT solutions

competitors.name: Apple
strengths: Consumer reach through wearables (Apple Watch, HealthKit)
Strong brand and ecosystem integration
Focus on preventive health and wellness

competitors.name: Teladoc Health
strengths: Global leader in telemedicine and virtual care
Diverse service offerings (chronic care, mental health, primary care)
Strong growth and brand recognition

company_competitive_advantages: Ability to integrate advanced AI and analytics for improved diagnostics and personalized care.
Strong partnerships with healthcare providers and payers.
Interoperable platforms that facilitate data exchange across systems.
Robust data privacy and cybersecurity measures.
Scalable cloud-based solutions and global reach.
barriers_to_entry: Complex and evolving regulatory requirements across jurisdictions.
High capital requirements for R&D, clinical validation, and compliance.
Need for interoperability with legacy healthcare IT systems.
Vendor lock-in and dominance of established EHR/IT providers.
Data privacy, security, and compliance with standards like HIPAA and GDPR.
Resistance to change among healthcare professionals and institutions.
Challenges in achieving market acceptance and demonstrating clinical/economic value.
market_analysis.market_timing_assessment: Favorable. The market is in a strong growth phase, driven by digital transformation, increased investment, and rising demand for innovative healthcare solutions. However, regulatory complexity and competition are intensifying.
market_analysis.regulatory_environment: The global regulatory environment for health-tech is complex and rapidly evolving. Key frameworks include the FDA (US), EMA (Europe), and WHO guidelines, with additional national and regional requirements. Regulations focus on patient safety, efficacy, data privacy (e.g., HIPAA, GDPR), cybersecurity, and interoperability. Recent years have seen increased harmonization efforts, but significant differences remain across jurisdictions. Companies must navigate a patchwork of laws, requiring substantial legal and compliance resources. Regulatory approval processes can be lengthy and resource-intensive, particularly for novel digital health solutions and AI-driven products.

investment_assessment.overall_criteria_summary: emwillcare meets all six Flight Story investment criteria. The company operates in healthtech, directly aligns with the mission of creating a healthier, happier humanity, and offers an innovative, AI-driven solution to a major unmet need in dementia care. The founder, Dr Emma Williams, has previously founded a relevant behavioural consultancy in dementia care, has held senior roles at Microsoft, and demonstrates exceptional strategic and intellectual capability.
key_risk_factors: Early stage: No revenue or significant commercial traction yet.
Highly competitive and regulated healthtech market with significant barriers to entry.
Product-market fit and scalability for B2B SaaS in care homes is unproven.
Dependence on founder's unique expertise and reputation.
Lengthy sales cycles and procurement processes in healthcare sector.
Potential challenges in clinical validation and regulatory compliance for AI-driven health solutions.
key_opportunities: First-mover advantage in AI-driven behavioural support for dementia care.
Large and rapidly growing market for dementia care and digital health solutions.
Strong founder credibility and unique expertise in behavioural science for dementia.
Potential for significant impact on quality of life, care costs, and medication reduction.
Support from Alzheimer's Society Launchpad and Business Wales Accelerator.
Scalable SaaS model with potential for global expansion.
investment_assessment.investment_thesis_summary: emwillcare is a mission-driven healthtech startup with a visionary founder and a differentiated, AI-powered solution addressing a massive, underserved problem in dementia care. The founder's unique expertise, prior relevant entrepreneurial experience, and impressive leadership background at Microsoft position the company for success. The solution is innovative, impactful, and aligns closely with Flight Story's thesis. While early-stage risks are present, the opportunity for outsized impact and returns is compelling.
investment_assessment.potential_return_profile: High risk, high reward. If emwillcare achieves product-market fit and scales its SaaS platform across care providers, the return potential is significant given the large and growing dementia care market. Early-stage status and regulatory hurdles increase risk, but first-mover advantage and founder credibility provide strong upside.
investment_assessment.deal_terms_summary: Raising £250-500k at a sub-£1m valuation, with 100% founder equity pre-round. SEIS/EIS advance assurance in place. No prior funding raised.
recommended_next_steps: Proceed to partner meeting for further diligence.
Request detailed financial projections, go-to-market plan, and customer pipeline.
Validate founder's prior consultancy business and confirm traction/impact.
Assess regulatory and clinical validation roadmap for AI product.
Explore potential for strategic partnership and value-add from Flight Story/SB.
Conduct reference checks with Alzheimer's Society Launchpad and Business Wales Accelerator.
